awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Nonlinear Dynamics of Assemblies at High Temperatures
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER project will support research that will contribute new knowledge related to the failure of structures that operate at high temperatures. This is particularly important for engines, such as the aeroturbines found on jets, or the gas turbines found throughout power plants. One challenge facing design engineers working on these engines is that they must design a structure that has to operate at temperatures often in excess of 1400 degree Celsius. Temperatures this high significantly change the way in which components perform; however, very little knowledge exists for how the specific fatigue (i.e. damage) mechanisms in these components evolve with temperature. This project focuses on fundamental research that can lead to the needed knowledge for improving the design process of these structures. The new knowledge will enable engineers to design more efficient structures that don't need frequent maintenance and will provide computational tools to predict the performance of a structure over its entire life cycle. This project is built on the PI's efforts to create a research experience that engages underrepresented groups, provides mentorship, and builds a peer and external support network.

The primary research objective of this CAREER project is to test the hypothesis that interfaces dissipate more energy in assemblies at high temperatures than predicted by fretting experiments or models calibrated to low temperature environments. A second objective is to apply the complex step theorem and the field of generalized complex number theory to create a new method for parameterizing nonlinear structural dynamics models as functions of temperature. To accomplish these objectives, both experimentation and theoretical advancement will be pursued. Experiments will focus on discovering how nonlinearities in structures evolve as a function of temperature, and how multiple nonlinearities interact (e.g. a rocket panel that has geometric nonlinearities due to in-plane stretching and interfacial nonlinearities due to bolted joints). In parallel, a new, parameterized reduced order model will be proposed that expresses the numerical model of a system in terms of temperature and will be validated by the experiments. This modeling framework is based on an extension of the complex step theorem to evaluate sensitivities of a system with respect to a specified variable through the introduction of generalized complex numbers in the system?s definition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to create a method to develop more efficient, lighter-weight engines as part of an effort to reduce our societal dependency on energy consumption. To achieve this, a new framework, termed Tribomechadynamics, was created that deliberatedly integrated tribology (the study of surface interactions, including friction and wear), contact mechanics, and structural/nonlinear dynamics. Using this new framework, the major activities of this research were:

1. Formulation and validation of a predictive model for the energy transfer and dissipation across jointed interfaces. In order to understand how to design more efficient engines, it is paramount to understand how energy is dissipated and transferred across the parts that make up an engine. This new framework improved our ability to predict this by orders of magnitude in both stiffness and dissipation capacity. It has since been validated against multiple structures.

2. Formulation of a new framework for coupling geometric and interfacial nonlinearities. Many aerospace structures and power generators (such as wind and gas turbines) involve large, thin, curved components that exhibit geometric nonlinearities (i.e., the more they deflect, the stiffer they become). Prior to this research, it was unclear how the interfacial nonlinearities (for example, friction where a structure is bolted together) coupled with the geometric nonlienarities. This work provides a new and more accurate framework to understand this behavior, thus enabling design optimization. In particular, this research has demonstrated that interfacial nonlinearities influence a structure's stiffness at low excitation amplitudes before giving way to the effects of geometric nonlinearities. The dissipative characteristics of an interface, however, are potentially increased by the geometric nonlinearities interaction with the interfacial nonlinearities.

3. During the pandemic, a community-wide research challenge was created to assess the state of the art for predicting the dynamics of structures with geometric and interfacial nonlinearities. Building on these predictions, the structure was fabricated and tested to identify gaps in our current knowledge. All data recorded is now freely available for researchers to study. In addition to data on the interaction between geometric and interfacial nonlinearities, the experiments showed that even a temperature change of 1-2 degrees celsius can significantly change the nonlinear dynamics of the entire structure.

4. To help train the next generation of researchers in the nonlinear dynamics community, a research camp was created that brings together graduate student researchers for a six week long collaborative research project every summer. This research camp provides graduate students with a deep dive on the foundational experimental and theoretical techniques for our field, it establishes a large, international peer network for them, and provides a number of external mentors for them in their community. Additionally, both undergraduate and high-school research components are included in the research program to help encourage students from under represented backgrounds to pursue STEM education through both participation in the research projects, lectures on topics of interest, and a broad introduction to multiple disciplines through science and engineering.

 


Last Modified: 07/15/2024
Modified by: Matthew R Brake

In order to understand how to design more efficient engines, it is paramount to understand how energy is dissipated and transferred across the parts that make up an engine. This new framework improved our ability to predict this by orders of magnitude in both stiffness and dissipation capacity. It has since been validated against multiple structures.
